snippet: In a campaign aimed at 18- to 34-year-olds, Levi Strauss is suggesting itself as clothing suited for taking on the world.
abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column on latest campaign for Levi Strauss, which is pitching its clothing to 18- to 34-year-olds who want to change the world; campaign is focused on empowerment while remaining grounded in style to avoid being too esoteric.

headline.main: Carpe Diem, Preferably in a Pair of Jeans
headline.print_headline: Carpe Diem, Preferably in a Pair of Jeans

snippet: Mr. Dandapani, 54, is the president and chief operating officer of Apple Core Hotels, a privately run company that owns and operates five midpriced hotels in Midtown Manhattan.
abstract: Vivian Marino 30-Minute Interview with Apple Core Hotels president and chief operating officer Vijay Dandapani; Apple Core Hotels is a privately run company that owns and operates five midpriced hotels in Midtown Manhattan.

snippet: The mobile payments start-up, best known for its pint-size credit card reader, is close to raising roughly $200 million, which would give the company an implied valuation of $3.25 billion.
abstract: The mobile payments start-up, best known for its pint-size credit card reader, is close to raising roughly $200 million, which would give the company an implied valuation of $3.25 billion.

headline.main: Square Expects New Financing and a Loftier Value
headline.print_headline: Square Looks to New Financing and Loftier Value

snippet: Apple sold 28 percent more iPhones last quarter than it did a year earlier, but the growth failed to meet the lofty expectations of analysts.
abstract: Apple sells 28 percent more iPhones in the most recent quarter than it did a year earlier, but growth fails to meet analyst expectations as customers wait for the latest model, leading to a rare earnings disappointment from the company; Apple reports net income of $8.82 billion, or $9.32 a share, up from $7.31 billion, or $7.79 a share, in the period a year earlier; revenue was $35.02 billion compared with $28.57 billion a year earlier.

headline.main: Softer Sales of iPhones Hurt Apple
headline.print_headline: Softer Sales Of iPhones Hurt Apple

snippet: Mission Chinese Food does to Chinese food what Led Zeppelin did to the blues. It both pays respectful homage to its inspiration and takes wild, flagrant liberties with it.
abstract: Pete Wells reviews Mission Chinese Food on the Lower East Side.

snippet: The Dow led the sell-off, falling more than 100 points for a third straight session on worries that include the global economy.
abstract: Grim news, ranging from weak corporate earnings to a deepening European debt crisis, leads investors to a sell-off; Dow Jones industrial average experiences its third straight triple-digit loss; worldwide investors continue to sell stocks and seek the relative safety of United States government debt, sending the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note to another record low.

headline.main: With Little Good News, Wall Street Pulls Back
headline.print_headline: With Little Good News, Wall Street Pulls Back

snippet: For all of Square's challenges, raising money has not been one.     Square, the mobile payments start-up best known for its pint-size credit card reader, is close to raising roughly $200 million, which would give the company an implied valuation o...
abstract: Mobile payment start-up Square is said to be close to raising roughly $200 million in financing, giving the company an implied valuation of $3.25 billion, as it hopes to grow into a highly profitable business and a leader in the increasingly competitive segment. Photo (M)

headline.main: Square Looks to New Financing and Loftier Value

snippet: Sean Parker, the 32-year-old billionaire and former president of Facebook -- played by Justin Timberlake in ''The Social Network'' -- was sitting on the top floor of his town house in the West Village of Manhattan last month, lamenting that too fe...
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin Dealbook column on Napster co-founder Sean Parker, who laments that too few entrepreneurs continue taking big risks after great success, instead shifting into investment and venture capital; notes that Parker, along with his best friend and business partner Shawn Fanning, recently started the Airtime video chat service, proving they are exceptions to the successful-entrepreneurs-still-working theory. Photo (M)

headline.main: Taking a Risk, And Hoping That Lightning Strikes Twice
